verses.text: Now Sarai, Abram’s wife, had borne him no children. But she had an Egyptian servant whose name was Hagar.
verses.comment: The mention of Hagar introduces the servant’s role in God's unfolding plan. Sarai’s barrenness recalls other key women in salvation history who miraculously bear children (cf. Gen. 21:2, 25:21, Luke 1:7–13).

verses.text: So Sarai said to Abram, 'See now, the Lord has prevented me from bearing children. Go in to my servant; perhaps I may obtain children by her.' And Abram listened to Sarai.
verses.comment: Sarai’s solution reflects an ancient practice (cf. Gen. 30:3), but also shows impatience with God's promise. This passage foreshadows the theme of waiting for supernatural intervention rather than relying on human wisdom.

verses.text: After Abram had lived ten years in the land of Canaan, Sarai, Abram’s wife, took Hagar the Egyptian, her servant, and gave her to Abram her husband as a wife.
verses.comment: The explicit mention of 'as a wife' points to Hagar’s elevation in status for the purpose of bearing children, underlining both the human longing and the complexity of God's covenant plan.

verses.text: And he went in to Hagar, and she conceived. And when she saw that she had conceived, her mistress was despised in her eyes.
verses.comment: Hagar’s conception brings tension between her and Sarai, paralleling later rivalries (cf. the stories of Leah and Rachel, and Hannah and Peninnah).

verses.text: And Sarai said to Abram, 'May the wrong done to me be upon you! I gave my servant into your arms, and when she saw that she had conceived, I have become despised in her eyes. May the Lord judge between you and me.'
verses.comment: Sarai appeals to the Lord as ultimate judge, hinting at the seriousness of human conflict and the need for divine resolution—an early type of seeking reconciliation in God's presence.

verses.text: But Abram said to Sarai, 'Look, your servant is in your hand; do to her as you think best.' Then Sarai dealt harshly with her, and she fled from her presence.
verses.comment: Abram delegates the decision to Sarai, resulting in suffering for Hagar. This is a warning against abdicating spiritual responsibility, a theme echoed throughout Scripture.

verses.text: The angel of the Lord found her by a spring of water in the wilderness, on the way to Shur.
verses.comment: The appearance of the Angel of the Lord often signals a direct manifestation of God, foreshadowing later theophanies and even the Incarnation (Exod. 3:2; John 1:14).

verses.text: And he said, 'Hagar, servant of Sarai, where have you come from, and where are you going?' She said, 'I am fleeing from my mistress Sarai.'
verses.comment: God's questioning recalls God's search for Adam and Eve (Gen. 3:9), highlighting His personal care and pursuit of the lost.

verses.text: Then the angel of the Lord said to her, 'Return to your mistress and submit yourself under her hand.'
verses.comment: Hagar is told to embrace humility and obedience—virtues that unlock blessings. This anticipates the call for submission to God's will even when difficult (Luke 1:38; Phil. 2:8).

verses.text: And the angel of the Lord also said, 'I will surely multiply your descendants so that they shall be too many to count.'
verses.comment: This echoes the promise to Abram (Gen. 13:16), demonstrating God's mercy extends beyond chosen individuals, foreshadowing the expansion of blessing to all nations.

verses.text: And the angel of the Lord said to her, 'Behold, you are with child and shall bear a son; you shall call his name Ishmael, because the Lord has heard your affliction.'
verses.comment: The naming by divine instruction is significant (cf. Gen. 17:19, Luke 1:13), revealing God's intimate involvement in human destiny.

verses.text: He will be a wild donkey of a man, his hand against everyone and everyone’s hand against him, and he will dwell in the presence of all his brothers.'
verses.comment: Ishmael’s role as the ancestor of many nations is linked to prophecy and the ongoing story of salvation history. His conflict foreshadows the struggles yet the fulfillment of God’s word.

verses.text: So she called the name of the Lord who spoke to her, 'You are the God who sees me,' for she said, 'Here truly I have seen him who looks after me.'
verses.comment: Hagar’s recognition that God sees and cares introduces the theme of divine omniscience and compassion—a key foundation for trust in God's providence.

verses.text: Therefore the well was called Beer-lahai-roi; it is between Kadesh and Bered.
verses.comment: The naming of places for divine encounters emphasizes the physical reality of God’s intervention in history, showing faith is both spiritual and historical.

verses.text: And Hagar bore Abram a son, and Abram called the name of his son, whom Hagar bore, Ishmael.
verses.comment: The fulfillment of the angel’s message illustrates God's faithfulness and the power of his word to bring about life even through unexpected means.

verses.text: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar bore Ishmael to him.
verses.comment: The specific age marks the timeline for the development of salvation history, underlining the patience and faith needed to trust God’s long-term plan. This passage invites reflection on submission to divine timing, foreshadowing ultimate fulfillment in the arrival of the true promised Son.
